headline: Contact the Guardian securely
standfirst: Some of the most important stories published by the Guardian have come from anonymous or confidential tipoffs. Here are some ways to get in touch.
navOneTitle: First, how do you want to contact us…

navsOne.copy: Choose if you don’t want third parties to read your material
Choose if you don’t want to reveal your identity

navTwoTitle: OK, now what kind of material do you want to share…

navsTwo.copy: Initially at least, you just want to speak to someone…
You have files that you would like to send to the Guardian electronically…
You have papers, disks or other physical media that you want to give to the Guardian…

cardsTitle: Ways to send us documents electronically…

pros: SecureDrop does not record where things came from.
We read your submissions on secure computers.
cons: You will need to download Tor software to access our SecureDrop system.
If you are being watched, the very act of using Tor may arouse suspicion.
cards.readMoreCopy:
SecureDrop is the most secure way to contact the Guardian. You can write messages and upload documents, and follow up with us later if you wish. All we get is what you send us and a codename that allows us to reply to you. SecureDrop records nothing else about you. To prevent interception at our end, we decrypt what you send us on a computer that is kept completely offline.

Get started

*Use a computer that you are confident is not being monitored((link to my computer security stuff)). *Install Tor Browser((link to https://www.torproject.org/)). *Follow the instructions at https://www.theguardian.com/securedrop ((can this be a link?)).

After that

*Remember the passphrase SecureDrop generates for you. That way you can come back as the same 'source' to view replies from us and correspond securely. *You don’t have to give us a way to contact you but it can be useful for us to be able to do so. It can also help us if you are able to provide some background about what is in the documents, and why you think they might be of interest to us. We can correspond with you on SecureDrop, or you can use SecureDrop to confidentially provide us with other contact information.

pros: Encrypted emails and documents are protected by both encryption 'keys' and passwords. The bad guys would need to know both to read your stuff.
You can send long messages and attachments, which is difficult using phone apps.
It’s easy to communicate directly with a specific Guardian journalist.
cons: PGP requires a bit of technical prowess to set up.
If you lose your 'keys' or forget your password, you won’t be able to read your own communication.
cards.readMoreCopy:
If you plan to write an email to a Guardian journalist about a sensitive matter, look into PGP encryption. Used properly, PGP should make a message or document unreadable to anyone except the person who sent it and the person for whom it was encrypted. You will use a 'public key' that belongs to the person you are writing to, but is freely available on the internet. This key turns your message into an unreadable jumble. Your recipient – and no one else – has a corresponding 'private key' which can unlock messages that were encrypted by their public key.

Get started

*For extra safety, create a new email account solely for corresponding with the Guardian.((link to my stuff on creating a new email)) *If you're using a browser-based service such as Gmail, Yahoo! Mail and GMX webmail, look into Mailvelope((https://www.mailvelope.com/en)) for encrypting messages in your browser. *Two popular applications for encrypting text and documents, which you can then paste or attach to emails, are Gpg4win for Windows ((https://www.gpg4win.org/)) and GPGSuite for Mac ((https://gpgtools.org/)). * Create your own public and private keys using any of these tools. * Encrypt your message and attachments with both your public key and that of the person you are writing to. You can find Guardian journalists keys at https://www.theguardian.com/pgp((can this be a link?))

After that

*Keep your keys and password safe and don't store them together *Email your encrypted material to us, along with a copy of your public key so we can reply to you also under encryption. *Remember to log out after sending the message. You may also wish to delete the history((link to my computer security stuff)) of the correspondence from your browser or email software.

pros: Apps such as Signal and Threema are encrypted in transit and on the providers' servers, so only the sender and recipient can read them.
Once you have set them up, they're as easy to use as regular text messaging.
cons: All phone communication involves the phone disclosing its identity and location, so mobile apps aren't great for anonymity.
Mobile apps often rely on the phone's own security to protect messages stored on the phone. So if someone gets your phone and manages to unlock it, they'll be able to read undeleted messages.
Long messages and attachments are tricky.
cards.readMoreCopy:
Secure messaging apps are great for getting a dialogue started with a Guardian journalist. They're easy to use and the journalist is likely to see your message very quickly. But you should avoid them if you wish to remain completely anonymous or don't want anyone to know you're speaking to the Guardian.

Get started

*Decide whether you want to do this on your normal phone or do you want to buy a less easily traceable phone for this purpose. *Install an app such as Signal (which has excellent security but requires you to disclose your phone number) or Threema. *If your app has a disappearing messages feature, consider activating it, so your messages self-destruct after a predetermined time. *Familiarise yourself with the app by sending inoccuous test messages to someone, before you use it for anything too serious.

After that

*Add the Guardian investigations teams Signal accounts to your phone contacts: - London: +44 7584 640566 - New York: +1 646 926 0436 - Sydney: +61 457 262172 (Please don't phone or send regular text to those numbers. You won't get a reply.) *Check our journalists' profile pages for other contact details. Google their name and 'the Guardian' and you should find it. *If you can't find the right contact details for the journalist, you could message an investigations team and ask them to pass on your details.

pros: Good for sending a series of documents over time.
Good for very large document sets (gigabytes).
cons: You'll need to correspond with us beforehand so we can supply you with access keys and passphrases
You'll need to know how to use FTP software.
cards.readMoreCopy:
we have a private Secure FTP server that uses password-protected keypair authentication. We can provide you with a unique user account to upload documents. These documents are automatically moved on receipt to an isolated environment.

Get started

*Contact us using one of the other methods to let us know what you want to send us. *We will provide you with a keyfile and password, plus instructions for how to access the SFTP site. *Read up on computer security ((link to my computer security stuff)) before sending us anything. *Install FTP software such as Cyberduck or FileZilla on a computer. *Create a bookmark for our FTP site and append your key file to the bookmark.

After that

*Connect and send us documents, then message us again to let us know they've arrived. *Tidy up on your computer: remove copies of files you don't want lying around etc. *We won't reply to you by SFTP so wait to hear from us through the original communication channel.

pros: Useful to initiate communication with a journalist to exchange contact information for more secure channels.
cons: Telephone communication is easily hackable and can reveal your identity and/or location.
It's not always easy to verify that the person you're speaking is who they say they are.
cards.readMoreCopy:
Although telephone communication is far from secure, it can be a practical way to get a conversation started and to exchange secure messaging identities.

Get started

] *Find the name of the journalist you want to speak to. You probably don't want to explain your tipoff to a switchboard operator. *Decide in advance exactly how much you want to tell us about who you are and how we can get back to you. The journalist you want may not be available when you call, so you may have to leave a message. *If you will need to share documents with us later, look at some of the other options in this guide before calling and decide what contact information you may need to provide to the journalist you plan to speak to. *Consider whether or not it is safe to call us from your work or home phone, or from any mobile phone that is associated with you. *If you buy a pay-as-you-go simcard to call us from a new number, think carefully about where and when you buy it, and how you pay for it. *Remember that mobile phone calls disclose the handset ID as well as the simcard.

After that

*Call us on one of these numbers: Sydney office: +61 (0)2 8076 8500 New York office: +1 212 231 7762 Washington office: +1 202 517 8904 San Francisco office: +1 415 919 5874 London office: +44 (0)20 3353 2000

pros: If appropriate measures are taken, conventional mail can be a reasonably good way to hide who you are.
If you don't want to meet a journalist in person, it's the only reliable way to hand over physical objects.
cons: Post can get hijacked or at least scanned in transit.
cards.readMoreCopy:
If you're not actually being followed it's fairly unlikely an envelope or small package will get intercepted.

Get started

*Stuff can go missing in the post, so consider how bad it would be to lose the material you're planning to send us. Can you make copies? *Think about whether or not you need to preserve your anonymity. Could the posting location give you up? How about the materials and packaging? *If you're very worried about the package being traced back to you, post it somewhere busy and make sure there is nothing memorable about your or the package's appearance. *Mail is scanned for dangerous compounds and objects. Don't include anything that could cause problems with delivery. *International mail needs a customs declaration; registered mail requires you to provide sender details.

After that

*Guardian US postal address: The Guardian 222 Broadway 22nd and 23rd Floors New York, New York, 10038 USA *Guardian UK postal address: The Guardian, Kings Place, 90 York Way London N1 9GU United Kingdom. *Guardian Australia postal address: The Guardian Level 2 19 Foster St Surry Hills NSW 2010 Australia
